source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_043_chunk1
evidence_span: The microstructural evolution of cold-rolled Zircaloy-4 sheets during agings at temperatures from the ambient up to 700°C is studied by thermoelectric power (TEP) measurements.

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: CANDU nuclear reactors use pressure tubes made of either Zircaloy-2 or cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: Small cracks have initiated and grown by delayed hydride cracking (DHC)

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: several such cracks grew through the wall of cold-worked (c.w.) Zr-2.5Nb tubes

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: The maximum length of any of these cracks prior to detection was 16 mm

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: the critical crack size (for instability) of a through-wall crack was known to be well over 50 mm for those particular tubes

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: a crack grew in a Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube, near the end fitting in Ontario Hydro's Bruce Unit 2 reactor, to a length of 27 mm prior to leak detection and removal

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: a Zircaloy-2 pressure tube in the Pickering reactor Unit 2 failed by unstable crack propagation
